comment.body: Can you change this to MIT?

pull_request.title: Adding armv8 crypto extensions to SHA256/224
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds the armv8 crypto extensions accelerated implementation of sha256 hashblocks from supercop. This was tested on a ROCK64, a RASPI 3B+, and on an Intel mac (to ensure I didn't break x86 builds by mistake).

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.) - **NO**
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.) - **NO**

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -30,7 +30,11 @@ endif()
 if(${OQS_USE_SHA2_OPENSSL})
     set(SHA2_IMPL sha2/sha2_ossl.c)
 else()
-    set(SHA2_IMPL sha2/sha2_c.c)
+    set(SHA2_IMPL sha2/sha2.c sha2/sha2_c.c)
+    if (OQS_DIST_ARM64v8_BUILD OR OQS_USE_ARM_SHA2_INSTRUCTIONS)
+      set(SHA2_IMPL ${SHA2_IMPL} sha2/sha2_ni.c)
+      # set_source_files_properties(sha2/sha2_ni.c PROPERTIES COMPILE_FLAGS -march=armv8-a+crypto)

pull_request.title: Adding armv8 crypto extensions to SHA256/224
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds the armv8 crypto extensions accelerated implementation of sha256 hashblocks from supercop. This was tested on a ROCK64, a RASPI 3B+, and on an Intel mac (to ensure I didn't break x86 builds by mistake).

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.) - **NO**
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.) - **NO**

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,132 @@
+// SPDX-License-Identifier: Public domain
+#include <stdio.h>
+
+#include <oqs/common.h>
+
+#include "sha2.h"
+#include "sha2_local.h"
+
+#if defined(OQS_DIST_ARM64v8_BUILD)
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) { \
+    do { \
+        if (OQS_CPU_has_extension(OQS_CPU_EXT_ARM_SHA2)) {  \
+            stmt_ni; \
+        } else { \
+            stmt_c; \
+        } \
+    } while(0)
+#elif defined(OQS_USE_ARM_SHA2_INSTRUCTIONS)
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) \
+    stmt_ni
+#else
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) \
+    stmt_c
+#endif
+void OQS_SHA2_sha224_inc_init(OQS_SHA2_sha224_ctx *state) {
+	oqs_sha2_sha224_inc_init_c((sha224ctx *) state);

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds the armv8 crypto extensions accelerated implementation of sha256 hashblocks from supercop. This was tested on a ROCK64, a RASPI 3B+, and on an Intel mac (to ensure I didn't break x86 builds by mistake).

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,132 @@
+// SPDX-License-Identifier: Public domain
+#include <stdio.h>
+
+#include <oqs/common.h>
+
+#include "sha2.h"
+#include "sha2_local.h"
+
+#if defined(OQS_DIST_ARM64v8_BUILD)
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) { \
+    do { \
+        if (OQS_CPU_has_extension(OQS_CPU_EXT_ARM_SHA2)) {  \
+            stmt_ni; \
+        } else { \
+            stmt_c; \
+        } \
+    } while(0)
+#elif defined(OQS_USE_ARM_SHA2_INSTRUCTIONS)
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) \
+    stmt_ni
+#else
+#define C_OR_NI(stmt_c, stmt_ni) \
+    stmt_c
+#endif
+void OQS_SHA2_sha224_inc_init(OQS_SHA2_sha224_ctx *state) {
+	oqs_sha2_sha224_inc_init_c((sha224ctx *) state);
comment.body: I added them because the generic OQS_SHA2_sha*_ctx structs contain a void pointer, and I was getting typing errors for using the more specific sha*ctx structs which contain a uint8_t pointer. This seemed like the easiest way to keep the OQS_SHA2_sha*_ctx structs general while not having to cast the void pointer to a uint_8t every access. Do you have any recommendations on how to do this in a simpler/cleaner way?
